Biphasic kinetics were observed upon mixing ATP with a complex of Rho and poly(C) RNA. An initial time-dependent increase in protein fluorescence was followed by a decrease in fluorescence (Fig. 2A). The fluorescence enhancement rate increased linearly with [ATP], with a slope of 2.5 ± 0.1 μm–1 s–1 and a y-intercept of 7.8 ± 2.5 s–1 (Fig. 2C). The fluorescencequenching rate increased hyperbolically with increasing [ATP], reaching a plateau value (kmax) of 47 ± 0.6 s–1 with a K ½ = 23 ± 1.4 μm (Fig. 2D). Because the rate of each phase depends upon [ATP], both phases are coupled to the ATP-binding step. The fast phase measures the bimolecular ATP-binding step, because the rate increases linearly with [ATP]. Comparison of the ATP-binding rate with and without RNA shows that the Rho·RNA binds ATP about 70-times faster than the RNA-free Rho. Thus, the ATP-binding sites are more accessible when RNA is bound to the Rho hexamer. The second phase, which was observed only with the Rho·RNA complex upon ATP-binding, must correspond to a protein conformational change, because the rate increases hyperbolically with [ATP] (23Johnson K.A. Sigman D.S. The Enzymes. Academic Press, Orlando, FL1992: 1-61Google Scholar). Because the kinetic parameters (kmax and K ½) of the second phase are close to the ATPase kcat (35–40 s–1) and Km (30 μm) values in the presence of poly(C), the second phase may be associated with either the ATP hydrolysis step or a conformational change prior to ATP hydrolysis. To determine whether the second phase was associated with ATP hydrolysis or a step prior to ATP hydrolysis, the binding of AMPPNP and ATPγS was measured. With the unhydrolyzable AMPPNP analog, only a time-dependent increase in protein fluorescence was observed (data not shown). The observed rate increased with [AMPPNP] linearly to provide an AMPPNP-binding rate of 0.017 ± 0.004 μm–1 s–1 (Table I). This rate is similar to that of AMPPNP binding in the absence of RNA. Thus, RNA does not stimulate the AMPPNP-binding rate. In addition, the protein conformational change that we observed upon ATP binding was not present upon AMPPNP binding. This might suggest that the protein conformational change is associated with ATP hydrolysis. However, the kinetics of ATPγS binding to the Rho·RNA complex were biphasic and similar to ATP. Mixing of Rho·RNA complex with ATPγS led to a transient increase in protein fluorescence followed by a decrease, similar to ATP binding (data not shown). The binding rate of ATPγS (2.3 μm–1 s–1) is similar to the ATP-binding rate, and the conformational change following nucleotide binding occurred with a kmax of 70 s–1 and a K ½ of 30 μm (Table I). Thus, unlike AMPPNP, ATPγS seems to be a good analog of ATP. The results with ATPγS indicate that the second phase represents a protein conformational change that occurs before ATP hydrolysis. It is possible that the protein conformational change represents RNA contacting the secondary sites in the central channel of the Rho ring, because this step is necessary for the hydrolysis of ATP (9Richardson J.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 5760-5766Google Scholar). Kinetics of ATP Binding to Rho·polydC—To explore the possibility that the protein conformational change following ATP binding is associated with the RNA contacting the secondary sites, we measured the kinetics of ATP binding to the Rho·dC100 complex. It has been shown that polydC binds to the primary nucleic acid binding sites that reside in the N-terminal domain of the Rho protein, but not to the secondary RNA-binding sites in the central channel of the Rho ring (24Wei R.R. Richardson J.P. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 28380-28387Google Scholar). polydC does not stimulate the hydrolysis of ATP (9Richardson J.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 5760-5766Google Scholar, 25Lowery C. Richardson J.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1977; 252: 1381-1385Google Scholar). After mixing ATP with Rho·dC100 in a stopped-flow instrument, a small increase in protein fluorescence was observed, but the ATP-induced conformational change characterized by the decrease in protein fluorescence was not observed (Fig. 2B). The lack of the second phase was not due to a defect in ATP binding to the Rho·DNA complex, because (as shown below) mant-ATP binds to Rho·dC100 at a stimulated rate. Because the protein conformational change is observed only with the Rho·RNA complex, the experiments of ATP binding to Rho·DNA support the idea that the protein conformational change is associated with the RNA binding to the secondary sites. Mant-ATP as a Fluorescent ATP Analog—We have investigated here the use of mant-ATP (Fig. 3A) as a fluorescent analog of ATP to carry out sensitive nucleotide-binding measurements. In many NTPase, it has been shown that the kinetics and thermodynamics of mant-nucleotide binding and hydrolysis are very similar to the parent nucleotides; hence, mant-nucleotides are widely used analogs (20Jameson D.M. Eccleston J.F. Methods Enzymol. 1997; 278: 363-390Google Scholar). The spectral properties of the mant fluorophore are ideally suitable for monitoring nucleotide binding by FRET from Trp to the mant fluorophore bound at the ATP-binding site. Fig. 3B shows the fluorescence excitation and emission spectra of Rho protein and mant-ATP. The emission spectrum of Rho protein overlaps with the excitation spectrum of the mant-nucleotide indicating the possibility of FRET. Before using mant-ATP in nucleotide-binding kinetic experiments, we measured the kcat and Km of mant-ATP hydrolysis. No hydrolysis was observed in the absence of RNA similar to what is observed with ATP. In the presence of poly(C) RNA, the kcat of mant-ATP hydrolysis is 6.5 s–1 at 18 °C (Fig. 3C), which is 5- to 6-fold slower than the kcat of ATP hydrolysis under similar reaction conditions. The Km of mant-ATP (48 ± 6.6 μm) is similar to the ATP Km (30 μm). These results indicate that mant-ATP is a good ATP analog that can be used to study nucleotide binding. Kinetics of Mant-ATP Binding to Rho—The kinetics of mant-ATP binding to Rho protein was measured by using the stopped-flow method via FRET. Rho protein was rapidly mixed with mant-ATP, and the time-dependent increase in fluorescence due to FRET was monitored by exciting Rho at 290 nm and monitoring mant-ATP emission at longer wavelengths (440 nm < λem < 460 nm). The kinetics of mant-ATP binding was biphasic (Fig. 4A). The fast phase rate increased linearly with mant-ATP concentration (Fig. 4B), with a slope of 0.07 ± 0.007 μm–1 s–1 and a y-intercept of 0.9 ± 0.1 s–1. The slope of the fast phase dependence is very close to the bimolecular rate of ATP binding (Table I). Similar biphasic kinetics but at faster rates was observed for mant-ATP binding to the Rho·poly(C) complex (Fig. 5A). The fast phase of the observed biphasic kinetics increased linearly (Fig. 5B) with a slope of 3.6 ± 0.1 μm–1 s–1 and a y-intercept of 6.2 ± 1.5 s–1. These values are very similar to the fast phase of ATP binding in the presence of RNA (Table I). Thus, it is clear that the fast phase represents the initial binding of mant-ATP to Rho or the Rho·RNA complex. However, the origin of the slow phase is less clear. The slow phase could represent a conformational change in Rho upon mant-ATP binding. Alternatively, we considered the possibility that the two phases in mant-ATP binding arise from the two isomers of mant-ATP; that is, the mant group linked to the 2′-hydroxyl versus the 3′-hydroxyl group. It is known that the synthesis of mant-ATP provides an equilibrium mixture of 2′- and 3′-isomer of mant-ATP with a yield of 35 and 65%, respectively (26Cremo C.R. Neuron J.M. Yount R.G. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 3309-3319Google Scholar). Therefore, we investigated the interactions of Rho with two additional mant-nucleotide derivatives, where the fluorophore was attached specifically to the 3′-hydroxyl (3′-mant-2′-deoxy) or the 2′-hydroxyl (2′-mant 3′-deoxy) of the ribose ring. Both the mant-dATP analogs bind to Rho·poly(C) in a single kinetic phase (Fig. 5, C and E). The observed rates increased linearly with [nucleotide], as shown in Fig. 5, D and F. The slopes indicated that the 3′-mant-2′-dATP binds slightly faster than the 2′-mant-3′-dATP (Table I). Thus, it seems that the two phases in mant-ATP binding kinetics are due to the slightly different binding properties of the 2′- and 3′-isomers. Mant-ATP binding was also measured to the Rho·dC100 complex. The kinetics of nucleotide binding is fast when DNA is complexed to the Rho protein. The fast phase rate increased linearly with nucleotide concentration to provide a slope of 0.5 ± 0.1 μm–1 s–1 and a y-intercept of 5.5 ± 1.9 s–1 (Table I). Thus, the binding of dC100 to the Rho hexamer increases the nucleotide-binding rate about 7-fold. Kinetics of Mant-ATP Dissociation from Rho—To determine the effect of RNA on the dissociation kinetics of nucleotide, we measured the off rate of mant-ATP in the absence and in the presence of RNA. Mant-ATP was pre-mixed with Rho and RNA for a short time (t1 = 10 ms to 1.0 s) using the three-syringe set up of the stopped-flow instrument to minimize mant-ATP hydrolysis (Fig. 6A for the double-mixing setup). After the short preincubation period, Rho·RNA·mant-ATP complex was chased with excess ATP. Dissociation of mant-ATP from the Rho·RNA complex was determined by monitoring the mant-ATP fluorescence decrease after excitation at 345 nm. Fig. 6B shows a representative time course of mant-ATP fluorescence decrease. The dissociation kinetics best fit to the sum of two exponentials. The first phase shows mant-ATP release close to 9 s–1, and the second phase, accounting for nearly 40% of the total fluorescence change amplitude, shows a slightly slower mant-ATP release of 3 s–1. We made sure that the rates of the two phases were not dependent upon the preincubation time (t1), which was tested up to 1.0 s. Fig. 6C shows that in the absence of added RNA, mant-ATP release is dramatically slower (0.07 s–1). The stopped-flow kinetics in this study show that the nucleotide-binding rates are much faster when Rho is complexed to RNA as compared with the RNA-free Rho protein. Nucleotides such as ATP, ATPγS, and mant-ATP bind to the Rho·RNA complex with similar association rates of the order of 106m–1 s–1. The RNA-free Rho protein, on the other hand, binds ATP and mant-ATP with a slow association rate of the order of 104m–1 s–1. The same trend was observed in the rate of nucleotide release from Rho. When RNA is bound to Rho, mant-nucleotide release is fast, whereas the RNA-free Rho slowly dissociates the bound mant-ATP. The 50- to 70-fold slower rate of nucleotide binding and the 40- to 120-fold slower rate of nucleotide release in the absence of RNA indicates that the structure of RNA-free Rho is different from the one complexed with the RNA cofactor (Fig. 7). It is known that the RNA wraps around and binds with a high affinity to the primary RNA-binding sites in the N-terminal domain of Rho (3Richardson J.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 1251-1254Google Scholar, 27Allison T.J. Wood T.C. Briercheck D.M. Rastinejad F. Richardson J.P. Rule G.S. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1998; 5: 352-356Google Scholar, 28Yu X. Horiguchi T. Shigesada K. Egelman E.H. J. Mol. Biol. 2000; 299: 1279-1287Google Scholar, 29Bogden C.E. Fass D. Bergman N. Nichols M.D. Berger J.M. Mol. Cell. 1999; 3: 487-493Google Scholar). Our results indicate that RNA binding to the primary sites causes a conformational change in the quaternary structure of Rho that exposes the nucleotide-binding sites at the subunit interface and renders them more accessible to the incoming and outgoing nucleotides (Fig. 7). This is in agreement with the result that the mant-ATP binding rate is stimulated by dC100, which binds only to the primary sites. The association rate of mant-ATP for the Rho·polydC complex is, however, only 7-fold greater than the association rate of mant-ATP to free Rho, whereas the association rate of mant-ATP for the Rho·poly(C) complex is 50- to 70-fold greater. Hence, the complex of Rho with RNA must be structurally distinct from the complex of Rho with DNA. However, this was not evident from the crystal structure of the Rho hexamer with oligo(C) and oligodC (10Skordalakes E. Berger J.M. Cell. 2003; 114: 135-146Google Scholar). The studies of nucleotide binding in this paper and the previous studies of RNA binding (13Kim D.E. Patel S.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 13902-13910Google Scholar) indicate that there is cooperativity between the nucleic acid and the nucleotide-binding sites. When RNA is bound to Rho, the ATP-binding kinetics are biphasic, and the experiments in this study provide evidence for a protein conformational change following ATP binding that results in RNA binding to the secondary-binding sites. The protein conformational change was observed with ATPγS but not the unhydrolyzable ATP analog, AMPPNP. Thus, conformational changes in the nucleic acid binding site are caused by specific interactions of the nucleotide with the Rho hexamer. Similarly, DNA does not stimulate the rate of nucleotide binding to the extent that RNA does, which indicates that DNA and RNA induces distinct changes in the nucleotide-binding sites. The protein conformational change as a result of ATP binding to the Rho·RNA complex occurs at about 47 s–1, which is very close to the rate of RNA-stimulated ATP hydrolysis (35–40 s–1). We propose that the Rho hexamer becomes competent in ATP hydrolysis and translocation upon undergoing this conformational change.

Two multiprotein E3 (ubiquitin-protein ligase) ubiquitin ligases, the SCF (Skp1-Cullin-1-F-box) and the APC/C (anaphase promoting complex/cyclosome), are vital in ensuring the temporal order of the cell cycle. Particularly, timely destruction of cyclins via these two E3s is essential for down-regulation of cyclin-dependent kinase. In general, G1 and S phase cyclins are ubiquitylated by the SCF, whereas ubiquitylation of mitotic cyclins is catalyzed by the APC/C. Here we show that fission yeast S phase cyclin Cig2 is ubiquitylated and degraded via both the SCF and the APC/C. Cig2 instability during G2 and M phase is dependent upon the SCF complex, whereas the APC/C is responsible for Cig2 destruction during anaphase and G1, thereby ensuring a spike pattern of Cig2 levels, peaking only at S phase. Two F-box/WD proteins Pop1 and Pop2, homologues of budding yeast Cdc4 and human Fbw7, are responsible for Cig2 instability. Pop1 binds Cig2 in vivo. An in vitro binding assay shows that an internal 93 amino acid residues comprising a part of the cyclin box are necessary and sufficient for this binding. Cig2 phosphorylation is also required for interaction with Pop1. We previously showed that transcriptional oscillation of cig2+ requires Pop1 and Pop2 function. SCFPop1/Pop2 therefore regulates Cig2 levels in a dual manner, transcriptionally and post-translationally. Our results also highlight a collaborative action of the APC/C and the SCF toward the common substrate Cig2. This type of composite degradation control may be more general as the regulatory mechanism in other complex systems. Ubiquitin-dependent proteolysis plays a crucial role in a variety of biological systems. In this pathway, ubiquitin is transferred via a series of reactions to substrate proteins, and multiubiquitylated proteins are degraded by the 26 S proteasome (1Hochstrasser M. Annu. Rev. Genet. 1996; 30: 405-439Google Scholar, 2Hershko A. Ciechanover A. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1992; 61: 761-807Google Scholar). Timing and substrate specificity of proteolysis are determined by a ubiquitin ligase or E3. 1The abbreviations used are: E3, ubiquitin-protein ligase; E2, ubiquitin-carrier protein; APC/C, anaphase-promoting complex/cyclosome; cdk, cyclin-dependent kinase; SCF, Skp1-Cullin-1-F-box; GST, glutathione S-transferase; HA, hemagglutinin. Two E3s that comprise multiprotein components are of particular importance for cell cycle progression. These are termed the SCF (Skp1-Cullin-1-F-box) and the APC/cyclosome (anaphase promoting complex, referred to as the APC/C hereafter) (3Peters J.-M. Mol. Cell. 2002; 9: 931-943Google Scholar, 4Deshaies R.J. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 1999; 15: 435-467Google Scholar, 5Zachariae W. Nasmyth K. Genes Dev. 1999; 13: 2039-2058Google Scholar). The SCF complex consists of three invariant components including Skp1, Cullin-1, and Rbx1/Roc1/Hrt1 and various F-box proteins. Skp1 and Cullin-1 are required for the structural organization of the SCF complex, whereas Rbx1 is a RING-finger protein that interacts with E2-ubiquitin-conjugating enzymes (6Zheng N. Schulman B.A. Song L. Miller J.J. Jeffrey P.D. Wang P. Chu C. Koepp D.M. Elledge S.J. Pagano M. Conaway R.C. Conaway J.W. Harper J.W. Pavletich N.P. Nature. 2002; 416: 703-709Google Scholar, 7Schulman B.A. Carrano A.C. Bowen Z. Kinnucan E.R.E. Finnin M.S. Elledge S. Harper J.W. Pagano M. Pavletich N.P. Nature. 2000; 408: 381-386Google Scholar). F-box proteins play a unique role in SCF function, as they interact with Skp1 via their F-box motif and simultaneously bind specific substrates, thereby acting as receptors that recruit these substrates to the SCF complex. The genome of each organism contains multiple open reading frames encoding F-box proteins, the number of which generally ranges from 15 to 50 (8Kipreos E.T. Pagano M. Genome Biol. 2000; 1 (Reviews3002)Google Scholar), and each F-box protein is responsible for recruiting individual substrates to the SCF complex (9Patton E.E. Willems A.R. Tyers M. Trends Genet. 1998; 14: 236-243Google Scholar). Structurally, F-box proteins consist of two domains: an N-terminally proximal F-box and a C-terminal protein-protein interaction motif. The latter includes WD40 repeats and leucine-rich repeats. Cell cycle progression is governed by the master kinase cyclin-dependent kinase (cdk), which consists of a catalytic cdk subunit and regulatory cyclin subunit (10Nurse P. Nature. 1990; 344: 503-508Google Scholar, 11Krylov D.M. Nasmyth K. Koonin E.V. Curr. Biol. 2003; 13: 173-177Google Scholar). Although metazoans have evolved to contain multiple species of cdk and cyclin subunits, unicellular organisms such as yeast utilize a single cdk molecule, Cdc2 in fission yeast and Cdc28 in budding yeast, which comprises distinct cdk forms by interacting with different types of cyclins (12Nasmyth K. Trends Genet. 1996; 12: 405-412Google Scholar). To regulate the cell cycle, cyclin levels must oscillate, thus cyclin proteolysis plays a central role in the down-regulation of cdk activities. Mitotic B-type cyclins such as cyclin A and B are ubiquitylated by the APC/C in a “destruction box”-dependent fashion (13Murray A.W. Solomona M.J. Kirschner M.W. Nature. 1989; 339: 280-286Google Scholar, 14Sudakin V. Ganoth D. Dahan A. Heller H. Hershko J. Luca F.C. Ruderman J.V. Hershko A. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1995; 6: 185-198Google Scholar, 15Glotzer M. Murray A.W. Kirschner M.W. Nature. 1991; 349: 438-441Google Scholar). In contrast, G1 and S phase cyclins such as budding yeast Cln1 and Cln2 and mammalian cyclin D and E are ubiquitylated by the SCF (16Koepp D.M. Schaefer L.K. Ye X. Keyomarsi K. Chu C. Harper J.W. Elledge S.J. Science. 2001; 294: 173-177Google Scholar, 17Moberg K.H. Bell D.W. Wahrer D.C. Haber D.A. Hariharan I.K. Nature. 2001; 413: 311-316Google Scholar, 18Strohmaier H. Spruck C.H. Kaiser P. Won K.A. Sangfelt O. Reed S.I. Nature. 2001; 413: 316-322Google Scholar, 19Feldman R.M.R. Correll C.C. Kaplan K.B. Deshaies R.J. Cell. 1997; 91: 221-230Google Scholar, 20Skowyra D. Craig K.L. Tyers M. Elledge S.J. Harper J.W. Cell. 1997; 91: 209-219Google Scholar). In fission yeast, intracellular levels of S phase cyclin Cig2 are subject to tight control during the cell cycle in which the Cig2 protein exists as a sharp spike pattern, peaking only at S phase (21Martin-Castellanos C. Labib K. Moreno S. EMBO J. 1996; 15: 839-849Google Scholar, 22Fisher D. Nurse P. EMBO J. 1996; 15: 850-860Google Scholar, 23Mondesert O. McGowan C.H. Russell P. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 1527-1533Google Scholar). This is achieved by both transcriptional and post-translational, namely proteolytic, mechanisms. We previously showed that the APC/C and the SCF coordinately act to keep Cig2 levels low outside S phase (24Yamano H. Kitamura K. Kominami K. Lehmann A. Katayama S. Hunt T. Toda T. Mol. Cell. 2000; 6: 1377-1387Google Scholar). The APC/C is required for Cig2 destruction from anaphase onset throughout G1 phase, whereas cell cycle-dependent transcription, peaking at S phase, requires the SCF. We showed that two F-box/WD repeat proteins, Pop1 and Pop2 (25Kominami K. Toda T. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 1548-1560Google Scholar, 26Kominami K. Ochotorena I. Toda T. Genes Cells. 1998; 3: 721-735Google Scholar, 27Jallepalli P.V. Tien D. Kelly T.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 8159-8164Google Scholar), homologues of budding yeast Cdc4 and human hCdc4/Fbw7, are required for this periodic cig2+ transcription. In pop mutants, the cig2+ transcript is no longer cell cycle-regulated, its level instead being constitutive throughout the cell cycle (24Yamano H. Kitamura K. Kominami K. Lehmann A. Katayama S. Hunt T. Toda T. Mol. Cell. 2000; 6: 1377-1387Google Scholar). We envisage that some transcription factor(s) responsible for transcriptional fluctuation of cig2+ is degraded via SCFPop1/Pop2, although the identity of this factor remains unknown. Interestingly, in addition to these two regulatory pathways, the third mechanism underlying Cig2 down-regulation is functional, by degradation of Cig2 during G2 (24Yamano H. Kitamura K. Kominami K. Lehmann A. Katayama S. Hunt T. Toda T. Mol. Cell. 2000; 6: 1377-1387Google Scholar). We have shown that this Cig2 instability during G2 is Skp1-dependent. However, whether this role for Skp1 in Cig2 degradation requires SCF function or whether it is specific to Skp1 independently of the SCF complex (28Hermand D. Bamps S. Tafforeau L. Vandenhaute J. Makela T.P. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 9671-9677Google Scholar) remains elusive. In the current study, we address the question as to how Skp1 regulates Cig2 stability. We have shown that Pop1 and Pop2 are in fact required for Cig2 instability during G2. Cig2 is also unstable during M phase, in which SCFPop1/Pop2 functions independent of the APC/C. Pop1 binds Cig2 both in vivo and in vitro. Domain analysis of Cig2 shows that the region required for binding to Pop1 is independent of the N-terminal “destruction box”; instead, the internal 93 amino acid residues containing the “cyclin box” are responsible in a phosphorylation-dependent manner. Strains and Fission Yeast Methods—Strains used in this study are found in Supplementary Table S1. Standard methods for Schizosaccharomyces pombe were followed as described (29Moreno S. Klar A. Nurse P. Methods Enzymol. 1991; 194: 773-782Google Scholar). Gene Disruption—The entire open reading frame of each F-box-encoding gene was disrupted using PCR-generated fragments (30Bähler J. Wu J. Longtine M.S. Shah N.G. McKenzie III, A. Steever A.B. Wach A. Philippsen P. Pringle J.R. Yeast. 1998; 14: 943-951Google Scholar). The 1.8-kb ura4+ or 1.6-kb kanr gene was amplified with flanking sequences corresponding to the 5′ and 3′ ends of the relevant genes. These fragments were transformed into a ura4/ura4 diploid. Ura+ or G418r colonies were selected on minimal plates lacking uracil or rich plates containing G418, respectively. Correct disruption of genes of interest was verified by colony PCR using two primers, one from the ura4+ or kanr marker gene and the other from the deleted gene. These heterozygous diploids were then sporulated on plates lacking nitrogen. Asci were dissected, and germination of haploid segregants monitored. Out of 16 F-box-encoding open reading frames, two genes (pof1+ and pof6+) are essential, whereas the remaining 14 genes are non-essential for cell division (31Katayama S. Kitamura K. Lehmann A. Nikaido O. Toda T. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2002; 13: 211-224Google Scholar, 32Lehmann A. Katayama S. Harrison C. Dhut S. Kitamura K. McDonald N. Toda T. Genes Cells. 2004; (DOI: 10.111/j.1356-9597.2004.00730.x)Google Scholar) Synchronous Culture—For hydroxyurea arrest release experiments, hydroxyurea (10 mm) was added to exponentially growing strains in rich YE5S medium, incubated for 2 h, filtered, resuspended in fresh rich medium in the absence of hydroxyurea. In some experiments, growth temperatures were shifted from the permissive (26 °C for temperature-sensitive and 30 °C for nda3 strains) to the restrictive temperature (36 °C for temperature-sensitive strains and 20 °C for cold-sensitive strains). In Vitro Binding Assay—Cig2/dm (destruction box mutant) (24Yamano H. Kitamura K. Kominami K. Lehmann A. Katayama S. Hunt T. Toda T. Mol. Cell. 2000; 6: 1377-1387Google Scholar) or Cig2 N-terminally or C-terminally truncated constructs, Cdc13, Cdc18, or Rum1, was labeled with [35S]methionine plus cysteine (Promix, Amersham Biosciences) in a coupled in vitro transcription-translation system (TnT, Promega). All the plasmids were subcloned into vector plasmids with PCR-based methods. The labeled proteins were incubated with Cdc2 kinase (beads) and GST-Pop1 at 30 °C for 30 min (input). The Cdc2 kinase was purified from nda3-arrested extracts (0.65 mg) by Suc1 beads. Then, GST-Sepharose beads (10 μl) were added into the input reactions and incubated at 4 °C for 1 h. Bound fractions were separated by centrifugation and washed five times with binding buffer A (50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 150 mm NaCl, 0.5% Nonidet P-40, 50 mm NaF, 60 mm β-glycerophosphate, 5 mm EDTA, 0.1 mm orthovanadate). The bound proteins were eluted with 50 mm GSH, 50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8.1. λ-Phosphatase Treatment—The dephosphorylation of Cig2 in binding assays was carried out by incubating the input Cig2 in 1× λ protein phosphatase buffer (50 mm Tris-HCl, 0.1 mm EDTA, 5 mm dithiothreitol, 2 mm MnCl2) containing 80 units of λ protein phosphatase (New England Biolabs) at 30 °C for 20 min. To inhibit λ protein phosphatase, the phosphatase inhibitor sodium orthovanadate (Sigma) was added at 2.5 mm final concentration. Immunochemical Method—Total cell extracts were prepared after boiling followed by disruption of cells with glass beads as described (25Kominami K. Toda T. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 1548-1560Google Scholar). For immunoprecipitation, cell extracts were prepared without boiling. Mouse monoclonal anti-α-tubulin (αTub) antibody (Sigma), anti-HA antibody (16B12, Berkeley Antibody), anti-Cdc2 antibody and anti-Cig2 antibody and rabbit polyclonal anti-Cdc13 antibody, anti-Cdc18 antibody, and anti-Rum1 antibody were used. Horseradish peroxidase-conjugated goat anti-rabbit IgG, goat anti-mouse IgG (Bio-Rad Laboratories), and a chemiluminescence system (ECL, Amersham Biosciences) were used to detect bound antibody. For immunoprecipitation, 1 mg of soluble cell extracts, 2.5 μg of anti-HA antibody (16B12, Berkeley Antibody), and a 30-μl slurry of Protein G-Sepharose beads (Amersham Biosciences) were used. The F-box Proteins Pop1 and Pop2 Are Required for Cig2 Degradation in Exponentially Growing Cells—Fission yeast Cig2 is unstable during most of the cell cycle, where Skp1, a core component of the SCF ubiquitin ligase, is needed for this instability (24Yamano H. Kitamura K. Kominami K. Lehmann A. Katayama S. Hunt T. Toda T. Mol. Cell. 2000; 6: 1377-1387Google Scholar). To ask whether Skp1-dependent instability of the Cig2 protein requires F-box proteins, all the 16 open reading frames encoding F-box proteins in the fission yeast genome were disrupted, and the steady state amount of Cig2 was detected by immunoblotting using anti-Cig2 antibody. As shown in Fig. 1A, although Cig2 levels were not up-regulated in most of the deletion strains, mutants carrying deletions in three F-box-encoding genes, pop1, pop2, and pof7, appeared to result in elevated levels of Cig2. To address the protein stability of Cig2 in these three disruptants, the half-life of Cig2 was next examined. Exponentially growing cultures of each deletion strain were treated with protein synthesis inhibitor cycloheximide, thereby shutting off de novo protein synthesis, and residual Cig2 levels were examined afterward. As shown in Fig. 1B, in pof7 mutants, Cig2 was as unstable as in wild type cells. Also, accumulation of Cig2 in this mutant was not reproducible (data not shown). In clear contrast, in pop1 and pop2 mutants, Cig2 was indeed stabilized substantially, and the half-life of Cig2 was >2 h, whereas in wild type cells under the same conditions, it was <10 min (Fig. 1, C and D) This result indicates that Pop1 and Pop2, but not the other F-box proteins, are involved in Cig2 degradation. Pop1 and Pop2, but Not the APC/C, Are Also Required for Cig2 Instability during G2 and M Phase—We next addressed Cig2 stability using synchronous cultures, which were blocked at early S phase by hydroxyurea and then released into fresh medium in the absence of hydroxyurea. It is known that Cig2 is degraded via the APC/C upon onset of anaphase (24Yamano H. Kitamura K. Kominami K. Lehmann A. Katayama S. Hunt T. Toda T. Mol. Cell. 2000; 6: 1377-1387Google Scholar). To exclude the potential involvement of the APC/C in Cig2 degradation during this experiment, a mitotically arresting nda3-311 mutant containing a cold-sensitive β-tubulin gene (33Hiraoka Y. Toda T. Yanagida M. Cell. 1984; 39: 349-358Google Scholar) was used. At each time point upon release, protein samples were prepared, and immunoblotting was performed with the appropriate antibodies. As shown in Fig. 2A (lanes 1-5) and 2B, the level of Cig2 was abruptly decreased between 1 and 2 h after release from hydroxyurea. This timing of Cig2 degradation coincided with the completion of S phase as shown previously (24Yamano H. Kitamura K. Kominami K. Lehmann A. Katayama S. Hunt T. Toda T. Mol. Cell. 2000; 6: 1377-1387Google Scholar). The level of Cdc13, mitotic B-type cyclin, on the other hand, remained unchanged during this period, confirming that Cig2 degradation under this condition does not require the APC/C. Cig2 degradation was, nonetheless, proteasome-dependent, as Cig2 was stabilized in the mts3-1 mutant, which was defective in subunit 14 of the 19 S proteasome regulatory particle (34Gordon C. McGurk G. Wallace M. Hastie N.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 5704-5711Google Scholar) (Fig. 2C). The requirement of Pop1 and Pop2 for Cig2 degradation was next addressed using nda3pop1 or nda3pop1pop2 mutants. In sharp contrast to the pattern of nda3 single mutants, in nda3pop1 double or nda3pop1pop2 triple mutants, Cig2 was stabilized (Fig. 2A, lanes 6-15, and 2B for quantification). These results suggest that Cig2 is degraded through SCFPop1/Pop2 and the proteasome during G2 and M phase. Pop1 Forms a Complex with Cig2 in the Cell—We previously showed that Cdc18, one of the SCFPop1/Pop2 substrates, forms a complex with Pop1 (25Kominami K. Toda T. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 1548-1560Google Scholar). If Cig2 is also a substrate for SCFPop1/Pop2, Cig2 is expected to bind Pop1 and Pop2. As shown below, this was indeed the case. The intrinsic instability of Pop1 makes it difficult to detect the Pop1 protein expressed from the genomic promoter (35Zhou C. Wee S. Rhee E. Naumann M. Dubiel W. Wolf D.A. Mol. Cell. 2003; 11: 927-938Google Scholar). Therefore, multicopy plasmids containing tagged Pop1 (Pop1-HA) under thiamine-repressible nmt promoter (36Maundrell K. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 10857-10864Google Scholar) were introduced, and immunoprecipitation was performed using anti-HA antibody. As shown in Fig. 3A, Pop1-HA coimmunoprecipitated with Cig2 (lane 3). This interaction was specific, as Cig2 did not precipitate in the absence of primary anti-HA antibody (lanes 2 and 5), and in addition, Cdc13 was not pulled down in the precipitates under the same conditions (lanes 3 and 6). As Pop1 and Pop2 act in the same pathway by forming heterodimers as well as individual homodimers (26Kominami K. Ochotorena I. Toda T. Genes Cells. 1998; 3: 721-735Google Scholar, 37Wolf D.A. McKeon F. Jackson P.K. Curr. Biol. 1999; 9: 373-376Google Scholar), we then addressed whether Pop1 is still capable of interacting with Cig2 in the absence of Pop2. Pop1-HA was expressed in pop2 mutants, and immunoprecipitation was performed as described above. As shown in Fig. 3B, Pop1 coprecipitated with Cig2 in this mutant as efficiently as in wild type cells (lanes 4 and 7). Again, an interaction was specific, as Cig2 did not precipitate in the absence of primary antibody or with an excess amount of HA peptide competitors (lanes 3, 5, 6, and 8). These results show that Pop1 forms a complex with Cig2 in the cell, and for this interaction, its partner Pop2 is not required. Cig2 Accumulates When Other Substrates of SCFPop1/Pop2 Are Overproduced—Rum1 and Cdc18 are two known substrates for SCFPop1/Pop2 (25Kominami K. Toda T. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 1548-1560Google Scholar, 27Jallepalli P.V. Tien D. Kelly T.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 8159-8164Google Scholar, 37Wolf D.A. McKeon F. Jackson P.K. Curr. Biol. 1999; 9: 373-376Google Scholar), and we previously showed that protein levels of Rum1 are greatly enhanced under the condition where Cdc18 is overproduced, and conversely, Cdc18 accumulates in Rum1-overproducing cells (25Kominami K. Toda T. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 1548-1560Google Scholar). This is most likely attributable to the competition between two substrates toward availability of binding with Pop1 and Pop2. Given the notion that Cig2 is a novel substrate for SCFPop1/Pop2, we next tested whether Cig2 also accumulates when other substrates of SCFPop1/Pop2 are overproduced. When Cdc18 was overproduced, Cig2 levels were up-regulated accompanied with co-accumulation of Rum1 (Fig. 3C). Similarly, in Rum1-overproducing cells, Cig2 as well as Cdc18 accumulated to high levels (Fig. 3D). This result substantiates the notion that Cig2 is a substrate of SCFPop1/Pop2. Phosphorylation of Cig2 Is Essential for Binding to Pop1—We next sought to examine binding characteristics between Cig2 and Pop1 using in vitro translation systems. At first, to assess binding capability and specificity, various full-length proteins were labeled with radioisotope, incubated with Cdc2 kinase, and then mixed with bacterially produced and purified GST-tagged Pop1 protein (GST-Pop1). The binding between radiolabeled proteins and GST-Pop1 was examined by pull-down with GSH-Sepharose beads. Proteins translated and labeled in these reactions included Cig2, Cig2/dm (Cig2 construct with a mutated destruction box), Cdc13, Cdc18, and Rum1 (Fig. 4A, lanes 1-6, and see “Experimental Procedures”). These pull-down experiments showed that GST-Pop1 bound Cig2 as efficiently as Cdc18 and Rum1 (lanes 7, 10, and 11), whereas GST-Pop1 did not bind Cdc13 (lane 9). Moreover, Cig2 was not pulled down by mock Sepharose beads (lane 12), indicating that the interaction depends on Pop1. Consistent with the independence of the APC/C in SCFPop1/Pop2-mediated Cig2 degradation, Cig2/dm was still capable of binding GST-Pop1 (lane 8). It is often the case that phosphorylation of SCF substrates is a prerequisite for their binding to F-box proteins and subsequent ubiquitylation (9Patton E.E. Willems A.R. Tyers M. Trends Genet. 1998; 14: 236-243Google Scholar, 38Orlicky S. Tang X. Willems A. Tyers M. Sicheri F. Cell. 2003; 112: 243-256Google Scholar, 39Nash P. Tang X. Orlicky S. Chen Q. Gertler F.B. Mendenhall M.D. Sicheri F. Pawson T. Tyers M. Nature. 2001; 414: 514-521Google Scholar). It was shown previously that this was also the case for SCFPop1/Pop2-mediated degradation of Cdc18 and Rum1 (40Benito J. Martin-Castellanos C. Moreno S. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 482-497Google Scholar, 41Jallepalli P.V. Brown G.W. Muzi-Falconi M. Tien D. Kelly T.J. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 2767-2779Google Scholar). The requirement of Cig2 phosphorylation for binding to Pop1 was, therefore, examined in the above binding assays by treating Cig2 with λ-phosphatase. As shown in Fig. 4B, it was evident that binding between Pop1 and Cig2 was abolished by phosphatase treatment (lane 5). Phosphatase activity was required for this inhibition, as simultaneous inclusion of phosphatase inhibitors blocked its inhibitory effect (lane 6). This result suggests that the interaction between Pop1 and Cig2 is dependent on phosphorylation of Cig2. Determination of Internal Regions of Cig2 That Are Required for Binding to Pop1—Having established the in vitro binding assay between Pop1 and Cig2, we sought to identify the domain within Cig2 that is necessary for an interaction with Pop1. For this purpose, various subclones of Cig2 that lack either N-terminal or C-terminal regions were expressed in the rabbit reticulocyte lysate system (Fig. 5A, lanes 3-6). Binding between translated proteins and GST-Pop1 was then examined as before. In the case of N-terminal truncations, subclones lacking 180 amino acid residues (Cig2-NΔ180) as well as deletions of 60 and 121 residues were still capable of interacting with GST-Pop1 (Fig. 5A, lanes 12-15). Again, interaction was specific as Cig2 without GST-Pop1 or with GST alone did not pull down Cig2 (lanes 10 and 11), and only Cdc18 and Rum1, but not Cdc13, bound GST-Pop1 (lanes 16-18). This result shows that N-terminal 180 amino acid residues of Cig2 are dispensable for binding to Pop1. As for C-terminal truncations (Fig. 5B, lanes 1-5), two constructs (Cig2-CΔ53 and -Δ106, lanes 10 and 12) were still positive, although binding of Cig2-CΔ106 was somewhat weaker. In contrast, the other two deletions (Cig2-Δ85 and -Δ190, lanes 11 and 13) did not bind Pop1. We do not know at present the reason that Cig2-Δ85 was negative, whereas the shorter Cig2-Δ106 could bind Pop1. It is possible some structural abnormalities specifically created in Cig2-Δ85 may hinder an interaction with Pop1. To delineate further the minimal region of Cig2 for binding to Pop1, an internal fragment containing 181-358 was constructed and expressed (Fig. 5C, lane 4). As expected from the above results, this fragment was indeed capable of binding to Pop1 (lane 12). Then, this fragment was further divided into two regions, 181-283 and 284-385 (lanes 5 and 6, respectively), and binding of each fragment was examined. It was found that only the N-terminal region (181-283) was positive (lanes 13 and 14). Also, a shorter fragment consisting of 181-273 (lane 8) bound to Pop1 (lane 16). Taking these results together (see Fig. 5D for a summary of the binding assay), internal 93 amino acid residues of Cig2 (181-273) are necessary and sufficient for binding to Pop1. Here we show that Cig2 is a novel substrate for the SCFPop1/Pop2 ubiquitin ligase. This conclusion is drawn from the following results. First, the Cig2 protein becomes stabilized in pop mutants such that the half-life is >2 h when compared with <10 min in wild type cells. Second, Pop1 binds Cig2 both in vivo and in vitro. Third, like other substrates of the SCF (38Orlicky S. Tang X. Willems A. Tyers M. Sicheri F. Cell. 2003; 112: 243-256Google Scholar, 39Nash P. Tang X. Orlicky S. Chen Q. Gertler F.B. Mendenhall M.D. Sicheri F. Pawson T. Tyers M. Nature. 2001; 414: 514-521Google Scholar), binding between Cig2 and Pop1 is dependent upon Cig2 phosphorylation. Coordinated Regulation of Cig2 Levels via SCFPop1/Pop2 and APC/C—Cig2 levels are tightly regulated during the normal cell cycle in such a way that it exists as a spike pattern only at S phase. Uncontrolled expression of Cig2 leads to cell lethality accompanied by mitotic defects including “cut” phenotype (24Yamano H. Kitamura K. Kominami K. Lehmann A. Katayama S. Hunt T. Toda T. Mol. Cell. 2000; 6: 1377-1387Google Scholar). The work presented in this study has established the coordinated manner of cell cycle-dependent Cig2 degradation via SCFPop1/Pop2 and APC/C ubiquitin ligases (Fig. 6). Continued from anaphase of the previous cycle, during G1, the APC/C is kept active and responsible for Cig2 ubiquitylation and destruction. Upon initiation of S phase, the APC/C is inactivated, and Cig2 levels show peaked accumulation, which is coupled with transcriptional induction. When S phase is finished, Cig2 levels are dramatically decreased via the SCFPop1/Pop2 pathway, and this down-regulation endures throughout M phase until onset of anaphase, when the APC/C is activated. To ensure this type of spike pattern, SCFPop1/Pop2 plays an addition role in down-regulating cig2+ transcription throughout all stages except for S phase (24Yamano H. Kitamura K. Kominami K. Lehmann A. Katayama S. Hunt T. Toda T. Mol. Cell. 2000; 6: 1377-1387Google Scholar). Furthermore, not only during vegetative cycles but also sexual development, Cig2 levels are repressed in order for the cell to conjugate (42Kominami K. Seth-Smith H. Toda T. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 5388-5399Google Scholar). In this process, the APC/C appears to play a major role. Phosphorylation Sites of Cig2—Binding analysis using a reticulocyte system shows that the internal 93 residues of Cig2 (181-273) are sufficient for interaction with Pop1. This region overlaps with a part of the conserved cyclin box (168-380), which is required for interaction with Cdc2. Consistent with this, we previously showed that the Cig2 mutant protein (Cig2-AAA) that is no longer capable of interacting with Cdc2 becomes stabilized in the cell (24Yamano H. Kitamura K. Kominami K. Lehmann A. Katayama S. Hunt T. Toda T. Mol. Cell. 2000; 6: 1377-1387Google Scholar). We show here that phosphorylation of Cig2 is needed for binding. There are 14 serine/threonine residues in the 181-273 fragment, in which one serine (268SP269) corresponds to the consensus cdk-phosphorylation site. However preliminary experiments suggest that the Cig2 mutant in this serine (268AP269) is still unstable. 3K.-i. Kitamura and T. Toda, unpublished results. It is possible that, although phosphorylation of Cig2 is required, unlike other substrates such as Rum1 and Cdc18, the Cdc2 kinase is not involved in Cig2 ubiquitylation by SCFPop1/Pop2. Alternatively, phosphorylation of Cig2 might be more complicated and performed by multiple kinases including Cdc2 as in cyclin E degradation in metazoan (43Welcker M. Singer J. Loeb K.R. Grim J. Bloecher A. Gurien-West M. Clurman B.E. Roberts J.M. Mol. Cell. 2003; 12: 381-392Google Scholar). It is also possible that Cdc2 phosphorylates non-SP/TP sites within this region. To address this question, detailed mutational analysis of Cig2 in potential phosphorylation sites will be needed. We previously suggested that Pop1 is not involved in Cig2 instability during G2 (24Yamano H. Kitamura K. Kominami K. Lehmann A. Katayama S. Hunt T. Toda T. Mol. Cell. 2000; 6: 1377-1387Google Scholar). This was based upon the data showing instability of the N-terminally tagged Pk-Cig2 in pop1 or pop2 mutants. During subsequent experiments, we realized that the instability of Cig2 observed in the previous study is unexpectedly attributable to epitope tagging of Cig2 rather than the authentic nature of the Cig2 protein. Although Pk-Cig2 was apparently functional, as it suppressed cig2 deleted strains, Pk-Cig2 behaved abnormally in terms of protein stability, i.e. unlike untagged Cig2, Pk-Cig2 is unstable in a pop mutant background. Epitope tagging of proteins is widely used and, as far as the tagged protein complements phenotypes derived from corresponding mutants, it is generally postulated that this tagged protein retains the same characteristics as the non-tagged wild type form. As shown here, this may not be always the case. We would like to raise the point that, depending upon the individual experiments, careful assessment of data, particularly functionality of tagged proteins, would be required. Binding between Pop1 and Cig2 in the Absence of Pop2—Although both Pop1 and Pop2 are required for in vivo instability of Cig2, in terms of binding per se, only Pop1 is sufficient, as Pop1 alone interacts with Cig2 both in vivo and in vitro in the absence of Pop2. This implies that either a Pop1 monomer or a Pop1-Pop1 homodimer is capable of binding to Cig2. It is of interest then how only Pop1-Pop2 heterodimers are involved in Cig2 degradation. It is possible that heterodimers are required for interaction with other components of the SCF, which results in Cig2 ubiquitylation. Alternatively, heterodimer formation might be necessary for an interaction between ubiquitylated Cig2 and the proteasome. In any case, our data indicate that binding between F-box protein and substrate is necessary but not sufficient for subsequent proteasome-mediated proteolysis. Implications of Cig2 Homeostasis by Multiple Ubiquitin Pathways—In animal cells, Pop1/Pop2 homologue hCdc4 is required for ubiquitylation of cyclin E in a phosphorylation-dependent manner (16Koepp D.M. Schaefer L.K. Ye X. Keyomarsi K. Chu C. Harper J.W. Elledge S.J. Science. 2001; 294: 173-177Google Scholar, 17Moberg K.H. Bell D.W. Wahrer D.C. Haber D.A. Hariharan I.K. Nature. 2001; 413: 311-316Google Scholar, 18Strohmaier H. Spruck C.H. Kaiser P. Won K.A. Sangfelt O. Reed S.I. Nature. 2001; 413: 316-322Google Scholar, 43Welcker M. Singer J. Loeb K.R. Grim J. Bloecher A. Gurien-West M. Clurman B.E. Roberts J.M. Mol. Cell. 2003; 12: 381-392Google Scholar). Thus Cig2 could be regarded as a functional homologue of cyclin E, except that Cig2 also contains the destruction box and is ubiquitylated by the APC/C. Whether or not cyclin A, which contains the destruction box and was co-purified with Skp1 and F-box protein Skp2 (44Zhang H. Kobayashi R. Galaktionov K. Beach D. Cell. 1995; 82: 915-925Google Scholar), is also ubiquitylated by the SCF remains to be determined. In budding yeast, it was suggested that Clb5 levels are regulated via the SCF in addition to the APC/C (45Bai C. Sen P. Hofmann K. Ma L. Goebl M. Harper J.W. Elledge S.J. Cell. 1996; 86: 263-274Google Scholar). At present, Cig2 (and Clb5) are, therefore, unique cyclins in which both the APC/C and the SCF are required for timely destruction during the cell cycle. It is conceivable that in higher systems that require elaborate control over cellular levels of key regulatory proteins, this type of composite degradation mechanisms may be more general. We thank Drs. Paul Nurse and Hideo Nishitani for providing strains and antibody used in this study and Jacqueline Hayles for critical reading of the manuscript. Ghα protein, which exhibits both transglutaminase and GTPase activities, represents a new class of GTP-binding proteins. In the present study, we characterized Ghα in rat uterine smooth muscle (myometrium) and followed its expression during pregnancy by reverse transcription-PCR and Western blot. We also measured transglutaminase and GTP binding functions and used a smooth muscle cell line to evaluate the role of Ghα in cell proliferation. The results show that pregnancy is associated with an up-regulation of Ghα expression at both the mRNA and protein level. Ghα induced during pregnancy is preferentially localized to the plasma membrane. This was found associated with an increased ability of plasma membrane preparations to catalyze Ca2+-dependent incorporation of [3H]putrescine into casein in vitro. In the cytosol, significant changes in the level of immunodetected Ghα and transglutaminase activity were seen only at term. Activation of α1-adrenergic receptors (α1-AR) enhanced photoaffinity labeling of plasma membrane Ghα. Moreover, the level of α1-AR-coupled Ghα increased progressively with pregnancy, which parallels the active period of myometrial cell proliferation. Overexpression of wild type Ghα in smooth muscle cell line DDT1-MF2 increased α1-AR-induced [3H]thymidine incorporation. A similar response was obtained in cells expressing the transglutaminase inactive mutant (C277S) of Ghα. Together, these findings underscore the role of Ghα as signal transducer of α1-AR-induced smooth muscle cell proliferation. In this context, pregnant rat myometrium provides an interesting physiological model to study the mechanisms underlying the regulation of the GTPase function of Ghα Ghα protein, which exhibits both transglutaminase and GTPase activities, represents a new class of GTP-binding proteins. Perez D.M. Baek K.J. Das T. Husain A. Misono K. Im M.-J. Graham R.M. Science. 1994; 264: 1593-1596Google Scholar). Transglutamination requires Ca2+ and is inhibited by GTP, whereas GTPase activity is inhibited by Ca2+. Initially identified as tissue transglutaminase 2 (TG2), 1The abbreviations used are: TG, transglutaminase; AR, adrenergic receptor(s); PLC, phospholipase C; PVDF, polyvinylidene difluoride; AppNHp, adenyl-5′-yl imidodiphosphate; RT, reverse transcription; GAPDH, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. Ghα is a member of a large family of transglutaminases that includes plasma Factor XIIIa, epidermal TG1 and TG3, or prostate TG4 (2Lorand L. Graham R.M. Nature. 2003; 4: 140-156Google Scholar). These enzymes catalyze the formation of covalent γ-glutamyl-ϵ-lysine bonds between proteins or polyamines and protein substrates. Such modifications play a role in different biological processes such as blood coagulation, epidermal differentiation, formation of copulatory plug in rodents, or extracellular matrix organization (2Lorand L. Graham R.M. Nature. 2003; 4: 140-156Google Scholar). Like other transglutaminases, Ghα consists of four domains: an amino-terminal β-sandwich and a catalytic core with the active site cysteine (Cys-277) for transglutamination, followed by two carboxyl-terminal β-barrels. The three-dimensional structure of Ghα complexed with GDP revealed a unique guanine nucleotide binding pocket located between the catalytic core and the first β-barrel and formed by residues coming from both domains (3Liu S. Cerione R.A. Clardy J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2002; 99: 2743-2747Google Scholar). By virtue of its GTP binding/GTPase activity, Ghα acts as a signaling molecule for α1-AR (4Im M.-J. Graham R.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 18944-18951Google Scholar, 5Im M.-J. Riek R.P. Graham R.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 18952-18960Google Scholar), oxytocin receptors (6Baek K.J. Kwon N.S. Lee H.S. Kim M.S. Muralidhar P. Im M.-J. Biochem. J. 1996; 315: 739-744Google Scholar, 7Park E.-S. Won J.H. Han K.J. Suh P.-G. Ryu S.H. Lee H.S. Yun H.-Y. Kwon N.S. Baek K.J. Biochem. J. 1998; 331: 283-289Google Scholar), and thromboxane receptors (8Vezza R. Habib A. FitzGerald G.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 12774-12779Google Scholar). α1-AR were, however, the most studied Ghα protein-coupled receptors. Activation by α1-AR induces exchange of GDP to GTP and dissociation of GTP-Ghα from the Ghβ subunit, which was recently identified as calreticulin (9Feng J.-F. Readson M. Yadav S.P. Im M.-J. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 10743-10749Google Scholar). GTP-bound Ghα interacts with downstream effector PLCδ1, thereby resulting in phosphoinositide hydrolysis and Ca2+ increase (10Das T. Baek K.J. Gray C. Im M.-J. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 27390-27397Google Scholar, 11Feng J.-F. Rhee S.G. Im M.-J. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 16451-16454Google Scholar, 12Baek K.J. Kang S.K. Damron D.S. Im M.-J. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 5591-5597Google Scholar, 13Kang S.K. Kim D.K. Damron D.S. Baek K.J. Im M.-J. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2002; 293: 383-390Google Scholar). Deactivation of this signaling pathway is triggered by GTP hydrolysis and reassociation of Ghα with free Ghβ subunit. Although α1-AR/Ghα coupling was well established in many cell types, the cellular responses triggered by this signaling pathway still remain unclear. Indeed, only a few studies have addressed the role of Ghα as a signal transducer of G protein-coupled receptors. The present study was undertaken to investigate the potential involvement of Ghα in myometrial α1-adrenergic-induced responses. It is well known that norepinephrine modulates myometrial contractility during pregnancy. Adrenergic signaling pathways are under the control of progesterone and estradiol, which regulate the expression of receptors (β-AR), heterotrimeric G proteins (Gsα, Giα, and Gqα), and PLCβ enzymes (14Vivat V. Cohen-Tannoudji J. Revelli J.P. Muzzin P. Giacobino J.P. Maltier J.P. Legrand C. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 7975-7978Google Scholar, 15Elwardy-Merezak J. Maltier J.P. Cohen-Tannoudji J. Lecrivain J.L. Vivat V. Legrand C. J. Mol. Endocrinol. 1994; 13: 23-37Google Scholar, 16Cohen-Tannoudji J. Mhaouty S. Elwardy-Merezak J. Lecrivain J.L. Robin M.T. Legrand C. Maltier J.P. Biol. Reprod. 1995; 53: 55-64Google Scholar, 17Mhaouty-Kodja S. Houdeau E. Legrand C. Biol. Reprod. 2004; 70: 570-576Google Scholar). Hence, during pregnancy under progesterone dominance, norepinephrine stimulates β-AR and α2-AR, which both activate adenylyl cyclase and increase intracellular concentrations of cAMP (18Cohen-Tannoudji J. Vivat V. Heilmann J. Legrand C. Maltier J.P. J. Mol. Endocrinol. 1991; 6: 137-145Google Scholar, 19Mhaouty S. Cohen-Tannoudji J. Bouet-Alard R. Limon-Boulez I. Maltier J.P. Legrand C. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 11012-11016Google Scholar). The latter second messenger induces myometrial relaxation by inhibiting the pathways leading to Ca2+ increase (20Wray S. Am. J. Physiol. 1993; 264: C1-C18Google Scholar). At term, when concentrations of estradiol rise, the β-adrenergic pathway becomes desensitized (21Simon V. Mhaouty-Kodja S. Legrand C. Cohen-Tannoudji J. Endocrinology. 2001; 142: 1899-1905Google Scholar), and norepinephrine acts on α2-AR (19Mhaouty S. Cohen-Tannoudji J. Bouet-Alard R. Limon-Boulez I. Maltier J.P. Legrand C. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 11012-11016Google Scholar, 22Mhaouty-Kodja S. Bouet-Alard R. Limon-Boulez I. Maltier J.P. Legrand C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 31100-31106Google Scholar) and α1-AR (23Limon-Boulez I. Mhaouty-Kodja S. Coudouel N. Benoit de Coignac A. Legrand C. Maltier J.P. Biol. Reprod. 1997; 57: 1175-1182Google Scholar). At this time, α2-AR shift to inhibitors of adenylyl cyclase, whereas α1-AR activate the Gq/PLCβ system and participate in the Ca2+ increase and uterine contraction. An intriguing observation is that α1-AR are expressed throughout pregnancy, although they are not efficiently coupled to phosphoinositide hydrolysis due to down-regulation of Gqα (16Cohen-Tannoudji J. Mhaouty S. Elwardy-Merezak J. Lecrivain J.L. Robin M.T. Legrand C. Maltier J.P. Biol. Reprod. 1995; 53: 55-64Google Scholar) and PLCβ isoforms at this period (17Mhaouty-Kodja S. Houdeau E. Legrand C. Biol. Reprod. 2004; 70: 570-576Google Scholar). We thus questioned whether these receptors could signal through Ghα to regulate response(s) other than contraction. Indeed, myometrial cells undergo proliferation during pregnancy, which is critical for uterine adaptation to fetoplacental growth (24Alexandrova M. Soloff M.S. Endocrinology. 1980; 106: 730-735Google Scholar, 25Engstrom T. Bratholm P. Vilhardt H. Christensen N.J. J. Endocrinol. 1997; 153: 393-399Google Scholar). Although many studies have addressed the regulation of such a process in physiopathological situations like uterine leiomyoma, very little is known about the physiological processes involved during pregnancy. For this purpose, we first characterized myometrial Ghα and followed its expression, at the mRNA and protein level, during pregnancy and at term. We also determined myometrial transglutaminase activity and photoaffinity labeling of Ghα in the absence or presence of GTP or α1-adrenergic agonist. Finally, we used a smooth muscle cell line to analyze the role of Ghα and its transglutaminase-inactive (C277S) mutant in cell proliferation induced by α1-AR. Materials—[3H]Thymidine (7 Ci/mmol), [α-32P]GTP (3000 Ci/mmol), and polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) membranes were purchased from PerkinElmer Life Sciences. [3H]Putrescine (33 Ci/mmol) and enhanced chemiluminescence reagent were from Amersham Biosciences. AppNHp, GTP, N,N′-dimethylcasein, Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium, fetal bovine serum, penicillin/streptomycin, phenylephrine, phentolamine, and putrescine were from Sigma. LipofectAMINE Reagent Plus was purchased from Invitrogen. Monoclonal anti-Ghα was from NeoMarkers and monoclonal anti-PLCδ1 from Upstate Biotechnology, and peroxidase-conjugated donkey anti-mouse antibody was purchased from Jackson ImmunoResearch. The cDNAs encoding wild type and mutant (C277S) Ghα protein, subcloned in pcDNA3, were kindly provided by Dr. R. M. Graham and Dr. S. Iismaa (Victor Chang Cardiac Research Institute, Sydney, Australia). Animals and Tissues—Sprague-Dawley rats were obtained from Janvier (Le Genest, France). The females were caged with males overnight, and successful mating was determined by the presence of spermatozoa in the vaginal smear (day 1 of pregnancy). Animals were sacrificed by cervical dislocation at days 5, 12, 15, and 20 of pregnancy or at term during the expulsion of fetoplacental units, following the guidelines laid down by the National Institutes of Health guide. The uterine horns were quickly isolated and cut open lengthwise, and the fetoplacental units were removed. The myometrium was then freed of adherent endometrium. Cell Culture and [3H]Thymidine Incorporation—DDT1-MF2 cells were grown in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum and 25 units/ml penicillin and streptomycin. For [3H]thymidine uptake, cells were seeded in 12-well plates and transfected (0.6 μg of DNA/0.12 × 106 cells/well) with expressing vector for wild type or mutant (C277S) Ghα constructs using LipofectAMINE Reagent Plus. The cells transfected with the empty pcDNA vector were used as control. DDT1-MF2 cells were then given fresh serum-free medium and allowed to achieve quiescence for 24 h prior to subsequent application of 10 μm phenylephrine for an additional 24 h. DNA synthesis was assessed following the addition of [3H]thymidine (1 μCi/ml) for a period of 6 h before the end of the treatment protocol. Cells were then washed with cold phosphate-buffered saline, and cold 5% trichloroacetic acid was added to precipitate DNA as described previously (26Breuiller-Fouche M. Heluy V. Fournier T. Dallot E. Vacher-Lavenu M.C. Ferre F. Mol. Hum. Reprod. 1998; 4: 33-39Google Scholar). The precipitates were resuspended in 0.5 n NaOH, and aliquots were counted by scintillation counting. Experiments were done in triplicate. For Western blot analysis, DDT1-MF2 cells were plated in 6-well plates (0.3 × 106 cell/well), and the transfected DNA of the empty vector, wild type, or mutant Ghα was 1.2 μg of DNA/well. RNA Preparation and Reverse Transcription (RT)-PCR—Total RNA was extracted from rat myometrium and liver as described previously (27Chomczynski P. Sacchi N. Anal. Biochem. 1987; 162: 156-159Google Scholar). The RT-PCR reactions were done with the kit from Invitrogen. Briefly, 3 μg of total RNA were reverse transcribed according to the instructions of the manufacturer, and the resulting cDNAs were stocked at -80 °C. A 0.05 volume of each RT reaction was amplified using specific upstream and downstream primers for Ghα and the internal control glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH). Primers sequences for rat Ghα (8Vezza R. Habib A. FitzGerald G.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 12774-12779Google Scholar) and rat GAPDH (28Tso J.Y. Sun X.H. Kao T.H. Reece K.S. Wu R. Nucleic Acids Res. 1985; 13: 2485-2502Google Scholar) were 5′-ATCTACCAGGGCTCTGTCAA-3′ and 5′-ACTCCACCCAGCAGTGGAAA-3′, 5′-CCATGGAGAAGGCTGGGG-3′ and 5′-CAAAGTTGTCATGGATGACC-3′, respectively. PCR reactions (40 cycles) were 94 °C for 2 min, 56 °C for 1 min, and 72 °C for 2 min, with initial activation of the enzyme at 94 °C for 5 min. For semiquantitative analysis, PCR cycle profiles were conducted, and the cycle number (25 cycles) was chosen from the linear portion of the curve. The resulting products were run on 2% agarose gel and quantitated by ethidium bromide fluorescence. Preparation of Myometrial Fractions—Rat myometrium and liver were homogenized in buffer A for Western blot analysis, in buffer B for transglutaminase assay, and in buffer C for photoaffinity labeling experiments. After 10-min centrifugation at 4 °C, supernatants were collected and submitted to 100,000 × g centrifugation at 4 °C for 1 h to separate plasma membranes from cytosol. Pellet containing plasma membranes was resuspended in homogenization buffer, and protein concentration of plasma membrane and cytosolic fractions was determined according to Bradford (29Bradford M.M. Anal. Biochem. 1976; 72: 248-254Google Scholar) with bovine serum albumin as standard. Samples were stored at -80 °C until use. Buffer A contained 50 mm Tris, pH 7.3, 100 mm NaCl, 2 mm MgCl2, 1 mm EDTA, 1 mm EGTA, 0.5 mm dithiothreitol, 0.32 m sucrose. Buffer B contained 10 mm Tris, pH 7.5, 1.4 mm EGTA, 12.5 mm MgCl2. Buffer C was composed of 10 mm Hepes, pH 7.5, 250 mm sucrose, 5 mm EGTA. The three buffers were supplemented with a mixture of protease inhibitors (Sigma). Western Blot Analysis—Proteins from rat myometrium and liver (20 μg of protein) or DDT1-MF2 cells (5 μg of protein) were separated by 7.5% SDS-polyacrylamide gels and transferred to PVDF membranes. The blots were blocked overnight at 4 °C in Tris-buffered saline containing 5% nonfat dried milk and were incubated for 1 h at room temperature with monoclonal anti-Ghα or anti-PLCδ1 diluted 1:500. Incubation with secondary antibody (1:10,000) was carried out for 45 min at room temperature. Immunoreactive bands were visualized by the chemiluminescence detection system and quantified. The quantification of Ghα and PLCδ1 expression was determined by densitometric scanning followed by computer analysis using the NIH Image 1.62 program. Transglutaminase Assay—The ability of plasma membrane and cytosolic fractions to catalyze the incorporation of [3H]putrescine into dimethylcasein was determined as described previously (30Iismaa S.E. Wu M.-J. Nanda N. Church W.B. Graham R.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 18259-18265Google Scholar). Briefly, 15 μg of proteins were incubated with 0.8% (w/v) dimethylcasein and 10 μm [3H]putrescine in a 50-μl total volume of buffer containing 40 mm Tris, pH 7.4, 10 mm MgCl2, 30 mm dithiothreitol, 0.4 mm EDTA, 0.2 mm EGTA, 20% glycerol. Reactions were initiated at 37 °C in the absence or presence of 2 mm CaCl2 or 0.5 mm GTP. After 40-min incubation, reactions were stopped by addition of 50% cold trichloroacetic acid. The pellets were washed three times with cold 10% trichloroacetic acid and solubilized with 0.1 m NaOH. Radiolabeling was measured by scintillation counting. Photoaffinity Labeling—Photoaffinity labeling of Ghα with [α-32P]GTP was carried out as described previously (4Im M.-J. Graham R.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 18944-18951Google Scholar). Plasma membrane fractions (200 μg of protein) were incubated with 10 μCi of [α-32P]GTP for 10 min at 30 °C in buffer containing 20 mm Hepes, pH 7.5, 1 mm EGTA, 0.5 mm dithiothreitol, 10% glycerol, 100 mm NaCl, 2 mm MgCl2, 0.5 mm AppNHp in the absence or presence of 10 μm phenylephrine, 0.5 mm unlabeled GTP, or 100 μm phentolamine. Reactions were stopped in ice; the samples were irradiated with UV light (254 nm) for 20 min and solubilized with Laemmli solution for 1 h at room temperature. The samples were then subjected to SDS-PAGE in 7.5% gels and transferred to PVDF membranes. The membranes were autoradiographed and then immunodetected for Ghα. The levels of labeled and immunodetected Ghα were determined by densitometric scanning followed by computer analysis using NIH Image 1.62 program. Statistical Analysis—Results were expressed as means ± S.E. Statistical significance was assessed by Student's t test for unpaired data. A probability level less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant. Characterization of Rat Myometrial Ghα—To assess the expression of Ghα in pregnant rat myometrium, we used RT-PCR technique and Western blot analysis. Rat liver where the expression of Ghα has been reported already was used as control. Using specific primers, we amplified a 520-bp fragment of Ghα from pregnant rat myometrium and rat liver (Fig. 1A, lanes 2 and 4). Control PCR reactions performed on nontranscribed RNAs indicated no contamination of the RNA preparations with genomic DNA (Fig. 1A, lanes 1 and 3). Monoclonal antibodies raised against Ghα stained a single band of the appropriate molecular mass (74 kDa) in plasma membranes and cytosolic fractions of pregnant rat myometrium and rat liver (Fig. 1B). Our results also show that the subcellular distribution of Ghα is tissue-specific (Fig. 1B). Indeed, Ghα is predominantly cytosolic in liver, while a high amount of this protein is associated with the myometrial plasma membranes. Rat Myometrial Ghα during Pregnancy—We examined the expression level of myometrial Ghα at different stages of pregnancy. Semiquantitative analysis showed that the level of Ghα transcripts, but not of the internal control GAPDH, is altered during pregnancy (Fig. 2A). Indeed, mRNA level of Ghα increased progressively during pregnancy, with pronounced changes occurring at day 12 of pregnancy (2-fold of day 5) and at term (1.5-fold of day 20) (Fig. 2B). Quantification of the immunodetected Ghα also indicated an up-regulation of this protein. Indeed, the amount of membrane-associated Ghα increased progressively during pregnancy (Fig. 3A). In contrast, the amount of cytosolic Ghα remained stable until day 20 of pregnancy (Fig. 3B), and a significant elevation (+35%) was seen only at term. Comparison of the subcellular distribution of Ghα during pregnancy was expressed as the membrane/cytoplasmic ratio. The obtained data illustrated in Fig. 3C revealed a progressive enrichment of plasma membrane compartment in Ghα during the course of pregnancy. Indeed, whereas the cytosolic localization of Ghα prevailed over membrane-associated Ghα at day 5 of pregnancy, this situation was completely reversed at the end of pregnancy (ratio of 0.56 at day 5 versus 1.5-1.8 between day 20 and term).Fig. 3Myometrial Ghα amount during pregnancy. A and B, quantification of myometrial plasma membrane (A) and cytosolic (B) Ghα at days 5 (d5), 12 (d12), 15 (d15), and 20 (d20) of pregnancy and at term (T). Data are expressed as percentage of T and are mean ± S.E. of nine independent experiments. The amount of plasma membrane and cytosolic Ghα in non-pregnant rat represented 50 ± 7% and 60 ± 6% of term value, respectively. a, p < 0.05 compared with expression at d5. b, p < 0.05 compared with expression at d12 or d15. C, ratio of membrane/cytosolic Ghα during pregnancy (d5, d12, d15, and d20) and at T. Data are mean ± S.E. of four independent experiments. a, p < 0.05 compared with d5. b, p < 0.05 compared with d12. c, p < 0.05 compared with d15.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) Altogether, these results indicate an up-regulation of rat myometrial Ghα during pregnancy. Moreover, this period is associated with a preferential increase of membrane-bound Ghα. Myomerial Transglutaminase Activity during Pregnancy—Ghα is a bifunctional enzyme with both transglutaminase and GTPase activities. To characterize myometrial transglutaminase activity, we tested the ability of plasma membrane and cytosolic fractions to catalyze, in vitro, the incorporation of [3H]putrescine into dimethylcasein. Addition of 2 mm CaCl2 increased transglutaminase activity in both plasma membrane and cytosolic fractions of pregnant rat myometrium (6.4-fold and 4.8-fold above basal in the plasma membrane and the cytosol, respectively) (Fig. 4A). To evaluate the degree of participation of Ghα in this myometrial activity, we tested the inhibitory effect of GTP. As shown in Fig. 4A, 0.5 mm GTP blocked ∼90% of Ca2+-stimulated transglutaminase activity in plasma membrane and cytosolic compartments. We also examined myometrial transglutaminase activity at different stages of pregnancy. In the absence of Ca2+, plasma membrane and cytosolic transglutaminase activity did not change throughout pregnancy (a mean of 121 and 66 fmol/mg of protein/min in plasma membrane and cytosol, respectively). Addition of Ca2+ significantly increased transglutaminase activity, and GTP counteracted this elevation in both fractions at all stages of pregnancy studied (data not shown). As illustrated in Fig. 4, B and C, Ca2+-stimulated activity of the plasma membrane fraction increased progressively during pregnancy, whereas the cytosolic transglutaminase activity was stable until day 20 of pregnancy. In correlation with Western blot analysis, a significant increase (+30%) of the cytosolic transglutaminase activity was observed only at term (Fig. 4C). Functional Coupling of Myometrial α1-AR to Ghα—We next analyzed whether myometrial Ghα, by virtue of its GTP binding activity, interacts with α1-AR. For this purpose, plasma membrane preparations were incubated with [α-32P]GTP in the absence or presence of 10 μm phenylephrine (α1-adrenergic agonist). Labeled G proteins were then separated by electrophoresis and transferred to PVDF membranes prior to autoradiography and immunodetection. The molecular mass of the 74-kDa radiolabeled protein coincided with that of the immunoreactive Ghα detected by Western blot analysis (Fig. 5A, top and bottom). Addition of unlabeled GTP completely blocked labeling of Ghα (Fig. 5A, top). Moreover, application of phenylephrine significantly augmented photoaffinity labeling of Ghα (140-160% of basal) at all stages of pregnancy studied (Fig. 5, A (top) and B). These responses were blocked by addition of phentolamine, an α1-adrenergic antagonist (data not shown). Interestingly, both basal and phenylephrine-stimulated [α-32P]GTP labeling of Ghα increased during pregnancy (Fig. 5B). The maximal amounts were observed between day 20 of pregnancy and term. In this comparative study, labeled Ghα was hardly detectable at day 5 of pregnancy, even in the presence of phenylephrine. Ghα in DDT1-MF2 Smooth Muscle Cell Line—α1-AR/Ghα coupling was shown to activate PLCδ1, thereby resulting in phosphoinositide hydrolysis and Ca2+ increase (11Feng J.-F. Rhee S.G. Im M.-J. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 16451-16454Google Scholar, 13Kang S.K. Kim D.K. Damron D.S. Baek K.J. Im M.-J. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2002; 293: 383-390Google Scholar). To investigate whether such activation occurs in pregnant rat myometrium, we first characterized the expression of PLCδ1. Results illustrated in Fig. 6A indicated the presence of this PLC enzyme in non-pregnant, pregnant, and term rat myometrium. However, the amount of PLCδ1 during pregnancy represents only 30% of that observed in term rat animals (Fig. 6B). Pregnancy-dependent down-regulation of PLCδ1 is in correlation with the fact that all pathways leading to Ca2+ increase and contraction are inhibited or reduced during pregnancy. We thus asked whether α1-AR/Ghα coupling could be involved in myometrial proliferation. To answer this question, we used the DDT1-MF2 cell line, which was described previously as a useful model to study the myometrial adrenergic signaling pathway regulations (31Marjamaki A. Sato M. Bouet-Alard R. Yang Q. Limon-Boulez I. Legrand C. Lanier S.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 16466-16473Google Scholar, 32Limon-Boulez I. Bouet-Alard R. Gettys T.W. Lanier S.M. Maltier J.P. Legrand C. Mol. Pharmacol. 2001; 59: 331-338Google Scholar). As myometrial cells, this smooth muscle cell line expresses endogenously α1-AR (33Leeb-Lundberg L.M. Cotecchia S. Lomasney J.W. DeBernardis J.F. Lefkowitz R.J. Caron M.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1985; 82: 5651-5655Google Scholar). Transfection of DDT1-MF2 cells with cDNAs encoding wild type or transglutaminase-inactive (C277S) Ghα successfully resulted in an increase of the amount of Ghα (Fig. 7A). Assessment of transglutaminase activity showed that addition of 2 mm CaCl2 enhanced in vitro [3H]putrescine incorporation into casein only in extracts derived from wild type-transfected cells, thus confirming the lack of this function in C277S-expressing cells (Fig. 7B). To determine whether α1-AR stimulate DNA synthesis through Ghα, serum-starved transfected cells were incubated in the absence or presence of phenylephrine. Fig. 7C shows that activation of α1-AR resulted in an increase of [3H]thymidine incorporation into control cells (+50% above unstimulated cells). Overexpression of wild type Ghα further increased phenylephrine-stimulated DNA synthesis (a mean of 90% above stimulated control cells). Interestingly, a similar response was observed in cells expressing C277S-Ghα (Fig. 7C). Therefore, these results indicate that Ghα, via its GTP binding/GTPase function, participates in smooth muscle proliferation induced by α1-AR.Fig. 7Overexpression of Ghα increased proliferation of DDT1-MF2 cells.
